snippet: A move by Iraq’s government to welcome a deadly insurgent group into its political system is adding to sectarian tensions and could tilt the nation’s center of gravity closer to Iran.
abstract: Move by Iraq’s Shiite-led government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to welcome a deadly insurgent group into its political system is adding to sectarian tensions and could tilt the nation’s center of gravity closer to Iran; the militant group, Asaib Ahl al-Haq, broke away from the fierce Shiite militia commanded by the anti-American cleric Moktada al-Sadr, who has strong ties to Tehran; the American military has long maintained that the group was trained and financed by Iran’s elite Quds Force, something that Iran denies.

byline.original: By JACK HEALY and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
byline.contributor: Yasir Ghazi and Omar al-Jawoshy contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: A move by Iraq’s government to welcome a deadly insurgent group into its political system is adding to sectarian tensions and could tilt the nation’s center of gravity closer to Iran.

headline.seo: Iraqi Moves to Embrace Militia Open New Fault Lines
headline.main: Political Role for Militants Worsens Fault Lines in Iraq
headline.print_headline: Iraqi Insurgents Take Up Politics, Raising Tensions
